title: Top 10 campsites in Canada [Photos]
text:
Monday, August 03, 2015 06:00 AM MDT Top 10 campsites in Canada 
Is there anything more quintessentially Canadian than camping? We've listed the top 10 camp sites across the country. Keep these parks in mind when you decide to pack your sleeping bag and tent. (Fotolia) andreusK - Fotolia 
Banff National Park, Alberta Canada’s first national park is world famous for its pristine jaw-dropping views of jagged snow-capped mountains, turquoise lakes and dense coniferous forests. During peak season, there are 2,468 sites located within 13 campgrounds offering a variety of services. Sites are assigned on a first-come, first-served basis. (Fotolia) Brenda Carson - Fotolia 
Jasper National Park, Alberta Jasper offers year-round camping on its 12 campsites with sightings of bighorn sheep and mountain goats common. The area around the Columbia Icefield Campground is considered the best of the Icefields Parkway. (Postmedia Network files) 
Grasslands National Park, Saskatchewan Grasslands is one of the few places where the Canadian prairie resembles its original form, with the only prairie dog colonies found in Canada. The park's only campground, the Frenchman River Valley Campground, is located close to trails and within hiking distance of the bison’s preferred hangouts. (Postmedia Network files) MIKE DREW/CALGARY SUN/QMI Agency 
Thousand Islands National Park, Ontario Always popular with boaters and paddlers, the park's campsites are located on 12 of the islands. For those who like a bit more living space, the park now offers rustic oTENTik cabins that can sleep up to six people on McDonald and Gordon islands, and at Mallorytown Landing on the mainland. (Courtesy 1000 Islands International Tourism Council) 
Parc national d'Anticosti, Quebec Situated in the heart of Anticosti Island, the park is considered one of the best kept secrets of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The island features breathtaking views of the sea with huge cliffs surrounding the bay, excellent bird watching opportunities and an underground cave. The park offers three types of accommodations on the island: lodges, camping and vacation cabins. For more info on accommodations, visit Parcs Quebec’s website . (Postmedia Network files) 
Gros Morne National Park, Newfoundland Part of the Long Range Mountains, the park’s mountainous rock dates back over a million years. Visitors can hike more than 100 km of trails through wild, uninhabited mountains and camp by the sea. The park offers 227 drive-in and eight walk-in campsites on five Parks Canada campgrounds. (Shutterstock) 
Fundy National Park, New Brunswick The biggest attraction of the park is the Bay of Fundy, where many come to see the world’s highest tides and to explore the ocean floor at low tide. A wide range of camping experiences is available in the park, from backcountry to RV hookups. One added perk for those who hate sleeping in a tent is the park's yurt accommodations. It's one of a few national parks where yurt rentals are available from Parks Canada. (Courtesy Parks Canada) 
Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario This is a great campsite for bird lovers (up to 250 species), canoeists (1000 lakes) and hikers. With over 12 developed campgrounds to choose from, Algonquin offers a variety of camping experiences from tents to RVs or yurt camping. Visit the The Friends of Algonquin Park website for more info. (Handout) 
Prince Edward Island National Park, Prince Edward Island This family-friendly park features beaches, giant shifting sand dunes, trails and Green Gables, home of Lucy Maud Montgomery’s classic novel Anne of Green Gables. Among the three campsites that are located within the park, Cavendish Campground is the largest and most popular with over 200 sites and an exclusive supervised white sand beach. (Shutterstock) 
Grand Beach Provincial Park, Manitoba Located on Canada's sixth largest lake, Lake Winnipeg, the beach is considered one of the best in North America with easy access from campgrounds to the beach. For campsite reservations, visit Manitoba Parks’ website . (Postmedia Network files) Article
